channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Covid-19:No new cases in New Zealand for one full week
item.description: There are no new cases of Covid-19 in the country today and just one active case left, as New Zealand marks a week since the last confirmed case.

item.title: Covid-19 live updates from NZ and around the world on 29 May
item.description: Auckland mayor Phil Goff says the Covid-19 crisis has delivered the biggest hit to the city's finances in its history. Follow the latest updates here.

item.title: 'Turd taxis' back on Wellington streets after brief reprieve
item.description: Wellington's 'turd taxis' are back in action less than a week after they were stood down.

item.title: National promises up to $100,000 for businesses hiring more staff
item.description: National says if elected, it will give small businesses a $10,000 bonus each time they hire more staff.

item.title: Heavy rain predicted for top of North Island from Sunday
item.description: Drought-stricken Auckland and Northland can expect a pelting of rain from Sunday, but it will not be enough to break the dry spell.

item.title: Heifer on the lam: Farmer seeks sightings of 'mildly agitated' cow
item.description: "Her mates that I sold were $800 each, so while it's not a fortune, it's significant and it's a hell lot of steak and hamburgers and stuff gone west if I can't find her."

item.title: Tūtira mai ngā iwi boosts US, NZ military ties: 'It's so infectious'
item.description: One of the country's best-known waiata has proven so catchy a US Defence Force musician says it's been "on a loop" in his head for weeks.

item.title: False complaint over abduction and assault at Western Springs, police say
item.description: Police have confirmed the alleged kidnapping and sexual assault of a young girl in Auckland on Wednesday was a false complaint.

item.title: Controversial Christchurch Cathedral plans open for public input
item.description: The public has a chance to have a say on the future of Christchurch Cathedral, following a move to fast-track its reinstatement.

item.title: Search for cause of yesterday's burst sewage pipe in Wellington
item.description: Workers are digging around a sewer pipe that burst in Wellington's central business area to try work out why it failed.

item.title: ‘Dunedin, A Pretty Good Plan D’: DCC spends $145,000 on new campaign
item.description: A new $145,000 slogan, aimed at enticing New Zealanders to visit Dunedin, is getting a D-grade from many online.

item.title: Farmers welcome freshwater reforms but enviromentalists want more
item.description: A new government plan to clean up pollution in the country's waterways is being met with a mixture of eyerolls, applause and mild panic.

item.title: New Covid-19 antibody blood test to check for undetected cases in Southern Region
item.description: Scientists expect the test to reveal some cases of Covid-19 that were missed because of initial rules around swab testing and potential community transmission.

item.title: Covid-19: Arts sector funding boost lacks a plan - academic
item.description: The government's allocation of almost $100 million for the arts sector lacks any vision for how it could help the country recover from the pandemic, an academic says.

item.title: Covid-19 rules relaxed just in time for Friday prayers
item.description: The move to gatherings of up to 100 people at midday comes just in time for Muslims to come together for Friday prayers for the first time in two months.

item.title: Auckland man who murdered mother jailed for at least 14 years
item.description: A West Auckland man who murdered his mother with a hammer has been jailed for at least 14 years.

item.title: Newest breeding pair of takahē released into ecosanctuary
item.description: Two young takahē have been released into Orokonui Ecosanctuary near Dunedin.

item.title: Councillor upset rates rise on way for Christchurch residents
item.description: Six Christchurch city councillors opposed to rates going up have been outvoted by their colleagues.
